review:
You get more than what you pay for
Let me clarify that I didn't get mine from Amazon but from Flipkart. And also I paid like 44300/-.Note:UI is bloated but there's no ads. The UI is also not something fancy like MiUi, Origin OS or One UI but rather pretty simplistic. But it does have all the practical features that you will love.Cons:The display brightness is severely lacking at around 800nits, quite opposite to the bold claim of 1400nits. I put my mum's S22 for comparison and sure enough the luminance is bad.Pushing that 2K resolution will pressurize the system a whole lot. Causing the memory management to be broken.The 50mp mode doesn't capture good details. Things get quite blurred when zoomed.Average stereo speakers system. But Dolby pushes the output significantly.Update(literally!):Guys the official Tiramisu upgrade changes the phone into something much cooler. The new shelf, Spotify integration, widgets, Apple like smooth animations, tweaked RAM management.Just buy this phone. At 45k this rn is the best device if you can live with a flat display.

review:
Unfortunate customer of Motorola Edge + facing call drop issue from day 1
I bought my Motorola edge + on July 17th in Poorvika Mobiles, Chennai, India. All along I was owning various Samsung mobiles and this is my first Motorola mobile. But, from day one I am facing frequent call drops, Wifi connection issues and now, other people can't even hear my voice.Really frustrating and i am cursing myself for moving away from Samsung mobile to your Motorola flagship phone.Following is my issue chronology; Motorola, please provide a replacement mobile as soon as possible. I am getting frequent disconnects of voice calls. I raised the complaint to the Poorvika Mobiles on day 2 and they suggested Factory reset the phone and try to  Change the SIM Card. I did factory reset twice or thrice and changed the SIM card. Even then I was facing the call disconnects. None of my family members' phones (Basic models) gets the call drops but unfortunately this Motorola flagship phone gets frequent call drops and the Mobile signal is very weak in some places of my home, which is not the case with other phones. Then, I tried to contact your chat support and they suggested doing the "Rescue" Option, downloading the recovery tool from your site. But unfortunately , i could not reinstall the firmware with the rescue option, the tool was saying i am entering incorrect model number, which is not the case. Then the chat support suggested taking the phone to the service center in Chennai India.I took the phone to Chennai Motorola service center on 14th August 2020 and they did the firmware upgrade ( I guess...) and asked me to use the phone over the weekend and test it. But unfortunately even after this, I was getting call disconnects and the Wifi signal is very poor in some places of my home. But other mediocre phones are not having any call drops or wifi issue atall. On Monday (18th Aug), I took the phone again to the service center and requested for replacement. But, they refused and they are suggesting to open the phone and check the hardware. :(I am was really disappointed, nowadays the phones are so intact and having this IP64, removing the phone once is not a good idea at all for a few weeks old phone, with our replacement.I have told them not to open the phone and provide the replacement. But, they refused and asked me to call the toll free number which is a nightmare again. I have to call 15+ times to get the call connected and the technician over the phone said to leave the phone in the service center and they will get back to me in a couple of days.Today (19th Aug), again a person from Motorola called and said they have to open the phone to identify the issue. My question is how a phone within a month will have all the hardware issues ???? and what is the problem in replacing the faulty mobile which created a problem in 2 days after purchase.And today evening (19th Aug) with heavy hearted, i thought of collecting the phone from the service center to use it with the frequent call drops (I don't want the phone to be opened).After collecting the phone, I asked the technician to install the SIM card and tried to call and check. Now even the MIC is not working, the other end of the line can't even hear my voice.I have never ever faced this kind of issue in any of my past 20 plus other brand mobiles. Please provide me the replacement mobile and bring up your customer support and customer satisfaction. I am  clueless now and After buying a premium flagship phone from Motorola for the first time this is the nightmare I am having. I have started sharing my frustration in all the forums.Phone : Motorola Edge +Model : XT2061-3Color:Thunder Grey

review:
Value for money. Ultra fast charging.
Big screen, still battery stays almost two days. Charges from 0 to 100% in 20+ minutes and lasts for almost two days ( i am not a gamer or youtuber). Very good compute and storage at this price. Removed bloatware using Android SDK. Cons: no sd card, no 3.5mm audio jack and hence need to spend more for a audio + charging accessories. Most audio accessories DAC is 16bit and 192k sampling max and has crappy sound quality. Search and you will find 32bit 384kbits DAC sampler and audio will be much better. Yes there are once with Rs.600 to Rs.3000 DAC in those cases and is an extra cost. Not using any iqoo apps or registered to app store to prevent bloatware. Disabled all via Android SDK. The gallery app was crashing causing the camera too crash while trying to view the taken snap. Reinstalled the app using SDK and it was working fine. The menu is not good. We cannot sort apps in alphabetical order. Did show 5G n78 bands in my 5g lab, which Samsung tab shows. Looking for a firmware upgrade for that.On screen fingerprint reader is good. No heating issues even while watching movie. It's slightly heavier than other models. Screen is not that smooth and feels easily breakable.

review:
Great phone with minor cavities.

Pros

1. Display - Lives up to the numbers. One of the greatest displays and the greatest in this price range. Period.
2. Camera - Surprisingly good. Usable right out of the gallery. Ready to post levels of detail and color science.

review: Op zich ben ik wel tevreden over de telefoon. Het toestel zelf is zeer goed, uitgezonderd van de batterij die niet lang mee gaat, maar dat is een algemeen probleem met telefoons de dag van vandaag. De andere minpunten liggen vooral aan de nieuwe Adroid versie, waarbij meer swipe acties zijn toegevoegd die conflicteren met swipe acties van de apps zelfs. Zo ga je bv in IG voor hebben dat de volgende foto in de reeks tonen de "back" actie triggered. Je kan de oude manier wel terugzetten, wat ik dan ook zal doen. Swipen naar boven heeft nu ook 2 acties, afhankelijk van waar je begint, maar met een hoesje is het dus zeer moeilijk om te swipen naar boven om alle openstaande apps te zien en zo apps te sluiten. Deze swipe up acties zijn ook zeer traag en niet echt responsive. Vroeger kon je 6 rijen apps op je home schermen plaatsen, nu is dat amper 5, terwijl er zeker genoeg plaats is voor 6, want er zit zeer veel ruimte tussen de rijen. Misschien is dit om heel kleine telefoons te ondersteunen, maar ze mochten er wel een instelling van maken Imho. Ondanks deze minpunten zijn er wel verbeteringen aangebrach aan Android die ik prettig vind. Zo was het zeer makkelijk om al mijn instellingen en apps over te dragen van mijn oude telefoon naar de nieuwe. Ik heb amper zaken handmatig moeten toepassen. Zo gaat ook de batterij safe mode al af van 20% en nog andere kleinere verbeteringen. Al bij al goede telefoon, maar wel wat prijzig. Op de doos staat "built to last", en ik hoop dat dit ook zo is, en eens langer dan 4 jaar met een telefoon kan doen.Less

review: Zeer mooi afgewerkte smartphone, voelt stevig aan, alleen de achterkant is van plastic, maar ziet er mooi uit. scherm is perfect voor alledaagse dingen, dus ook in de zon, ziet er ook mooi uit. CPU is vlot genoeg om de taken uit te voeren, had wel voor de prijs een snellere mogen zijn en ook het werkgeheugen had wel iets meer mogen zijn, maar voldoen voor dagelijkse taken prima. Foto's zijn goed te noemen, ook in het donker. De vingerafdruk scanner zit onder het scherm en is vlot, geen haperingen ondanks dat mijn vingers door mijn werk niet altijd even schoon zijn. Helaas is het geheugen niet uit te breiden en zit er geen 3,5mm poort op. Het toestel is wel waterbestendig wat ik erg prettig vind. Toch blij verrast met het toestel. Een aanrader voor wie kwaliteit voorop stelt.

review: I have a 1+6, which I've had fully 4 years and have been very pleased with it until the battery needed charging too frequently. I had get the list down to 3 potential choices of replacement phones: the Pixel 7 pro and iphone13pro. I went to John Lewis for advice in making a choice as I find their sales team excellent, the prices are usually competitive + the guarantee is for 2 years. The iPhone 13 pro ruled itself out as it had disappeared off the market everywhere while I was researching my choice. Tricky choice but I stumped for the product I knew. (I'm not a game player) It is larger than I thought I wanted but in fact is slim + fits nicely in my relatively small hands. The screen is brilliant - same rating as current 4K TVs I gather. There's no obvious bloat wear - the Oxygen take on Android is familiar to me + works swiftly and well. The transfer from old phone to new was a breeze + very quick - a double ended usb C cable and I had all the settings on my new phone. The sound is much better - now stereo with a speaker top and bottom. I've scored 4 stars as I haven't had it long enough to decide on the camera. The specification is in line with the Pixel (which is stunning) and better than that model iPhone. I bought the base level 128gb - it was adequate previously. Ram matches the Pixel too and is adaptable if necessary. The charging is fantastic - fully charged in around 30 minutes (I don't let it empty -32?). The 65watt charger+cable v comes in the box, as does a good quality bumper case and a pre-fitted tempered glass screen protector.Less

review: I've been a huge OnePlus fan for several years now, and the thing I liked most was them keeping their prices at a reasonable level in comparison to the mainstream competitor brands. It's a fantastic phone, with fantastic hardware, BUT, the price tag without some of the features other flagship phones from the bigger brands offer are keeping me from giving this phone a 5/5 rating. I cant justify suggesting this phone over other flagship phones now that it's in the $800+ price range, aside from the fact that I know my past phones from OnePlus have held up very well. With that aside, we purchased this phone to replace my girlfriends pixel with a broken power button that was causing involuntary restarts, and 911 calls. She loves it so far. The camera is crisp and takes fantastic photos/videos, though I do like the older camera UI that was featured on phones like the Nord N10 5g. Screen looks great, and the battery is definitely an upgrade from some of their previous phones, even given the larger screen size. It has plenty of resource power for your mobile gamer and heavy multi-tasker, and the fast charger is second to none given the lifespan of my previous oneplus phone batteries.(2+ years without real noticeable cell life degradation). I'd recommend this phone to anyone looking for flagship quality, and a solid piece of hardware for under $1k, and doesn't mind sacrificing a few "breaking edge" features.Less

review: This would be my second OnePlus phone and is replacing my three year old OnePlus 7 Pro. While I miss the 100% full screen of the 7 Pro, this was a very suitable upgrade. The display is great and the edges aren't as curved. The hole punch front camera is minimally distracting. Of course it is several years newer and has a fresh battery so battery life and speed is better. The default camera app is better than the 7 Pro but overall OnePlus is still behind the big names (Apple, Google, and Samsung) on their computational photography for those special magic features. But the huge space on the back for the cameras concerns me so I installed a glass cover. This made getting a case harder as some push on the glass. I use Ringke Fusion-X to hold it down on all four edges. (Photos show Ringke vs Supcase and the air bubbles that result). OnePlus seems to have made smart improvements to stock Android in their OxygenOS that don't seem too disruptive. Although I still use a third-party launcher and disabled their Shelf pull down. I miss the power button for mobile payment app - but this is a change by Google to Android 13, not the OEM's customized OS fault. The front in-screen fingerprint sensor doesn't seem as accurate as my prior phone. However, this could be due to a different brand of screen protector so I'll have to try again later.Less

review: There is a reason why Samsung and Apple basically dominate the market. Let me just say, moving forward I will entertain myself watching people review things, but I will NEVER take any of their word on any product. The phone looks nice. Build is great. Screen is just okay. At 50% brightness, my Samsung A52 blows the 10 Pro out of the water. Samsung still has the best panels, regardless the series. Vibration motor on the 10 Pro is absolute garbage. What is the point of having that highly touted slider on the top right if you DON'T feel any vibration? It is stronger when coupled with sound. But if you solely rely on feeling the phone vibrate, you WILL MISS EVERY NOTIFICATION!!! And sorry, but any hype about cameras is a lie. Again, my A52, in low light, blows this phone away. I tried many scenarios, and no matter what, it was an absolute breeze to just point and click with the A52. There is WAY too much obsession online about photo taking. I am not a photographer, and as such my life does not revolve around taking photos all day. I just need the picture to look good. In low light, say goodbye to a good photo with the 10 Pro, unless you take an hour to figure out all the ways you can better it with the built-in software. Sorry, I don't have time for that. At 900 bucks, it should be incredible regardless the user and experience level. If you have multiple windows open, forget about choosing to close them all at once. The feature appears to work, but when you go to see if all the apps have cleared, at least one will still be there. You have to swipe it up to get rid of it. At the end of the day, I just want for the thing to work. At 900 bucks, it needs to be short of flawless. It is not. I am seriously done with taking any advice of any reviewer online. Their whole thing is to get free stuff. Why else would they have the fancy cameras, editing of a video, etc. No way it is just a hobby. It makes sense that if they overly bash any product, they will not get anything pretty much moving forward from that company. They are beholden to that company to a big degree. Way too many of them review these expensive items in a way that make the product feel like it is the best thing ever. YOU have to try the product for yourself, bottom line. Oh, and face unlock when you lift the phone, it is great and the fingerprint sensor is fast, but the lift to wake to face unlock on occasion does not always work. And no, I don't care to wait for updates. I did not get a 900 dollars phone to wait on it to get better over time. I need it to be incredible at that price from minute number one.Less

review:
.
*OnePlus 10 Pro (256) vs Pixel 6 Pro (128)*

The OnePlus 10 Pro is a very good phone BUT if you want a fantastic camera, read on. Both phones are priced at about ‚Çπ70K so a comparison / buying guide seems relevant. The OnePlus disappoints with it's camera. Both are 12 mp, despite the large numbers claimed. Perfect*.
*Camera*
Pixel by far. Having said that the OnePlus 10 Pro camera is no slouch but it's not as good. This is the clincher. If the camera is a priority, read no further, Pixel it is.
*Display*
Both phones have excellent, 120 Hz, 3200 x 1440, colour accurate displays. The OnePlus display is flat and the Pixel has curved edges which in a case, are redundant.
*Styling*
Both phones look good. The Pixel has a very unusual, distinct look and an excellent finish. The OnePlus is more conventional but looks great too. The Pixel is sturdier. For me, styling and colour are less important as phones go straight into a case but the OnePlus comes in Emerald Green with a chrome edge (nice) and Black with a black edge. The Pixel comes in 3 dual tone finishes, Stormy Black (Dark grey), Sorta Sunny and Cloudy White and all 3 have a black camera bump.
*CPU*
The OnePlus has the Snapdragon 8 Gen 1 which is slightly faster in benchmarks but runs hot. The Pixel has it's own Tensor chip that's excellent, contributing to it's image quality plus it's fast enough, smooth and cool. 
*Storage*
At ‚Çπ72K, the OnePlus gives you 256GB and the Pixel is 128GB but unless you shoot a LOT of video or store movies, 128GB is more than enough. The OnePlus 128GB variant has just 8GB RAM so I've left it out.
*RAM*
Both come with 12GB LPDDR5 RAM
*Charging*
Here the OnePlus scores with it's Oppo 80W VOOC Charger charging the phone fully in 30 minutes. The Pixel comes with no charger and doesn't even live up to it's 30W claim. 23W tops, 16W average... It takes 1 1/2 hours to charge with a 30W PPS Charger (with a poor charger it can take 2 hours) but goes 0 - 50% in 30 minutes. The OnePlus drains faster but it charges so quick that this isn't an issue. Gets hot while charging.
*OS*
OnePlus comes with Oppo's ColourOS with an Oxygen look, the Pixel comes with pure Android, no skin. Both are good so this one would not go to either phone.
*Updates*
The Pixel gives you updates for 3 years. The OnePlus comes with fewer updates. Both are on Android 12 at this time. Pixel gets it's updates sooner.
*Privacy*
ALL Android phones lack privacy as Android is by Google who are known data gatherers. They're more transparent on the Pixel but it's no different on other brands.
*Charm*
Ultimately, you need to fall in love with your phone. The Pixel 6 Pro with that camera guarantees that. It grows on you. The OnePlus is what it is at first glance. For me, the camera is the selling point of any phone today so I would recommend the Pixel. It can be charged at night.
*_Pixel binning, simply put, groups 4 pixels into one, resulting in low noise and better image quality._
_Less

review: Upgrading from a OnePlus 8t I was worried losing 4g RAM and having half the memory like everyone else. However, phone has been fine in that regard. OxygenOS12 is definitely a work in progress and has a lot of bugs/glitches/kinks whatever you wanna call em but it's stuff I've been able to work past for now. We've all seen the JerryRigEverything video of the phone snapping in half but honestly the build quality is spot on. The back is silky smooth and feels great without a case. The cameras work just fine and have a different look than every other phone on the market. OnePlus has always had fantastic displays and this is no less amazing. All in all, I'm satisfied with my purchase.

But zoom starts to get less detailed after 3-4 times zoom. The front facing camera is about average and night mode about the same. Again, not a bad camera just not a great one, either. 90-100 on most features with a 75 for the camera. I'll easily recommend the OnePlus. From an overall standpoint, can't do much better.

review: I bought a OnePlus 5 in 2017, and it has proved to be an excellent phone over the last five years. Although it's still working well it was time for an upgrade, and so I chose the OnePlus 10 Pro 5G. It's slightly longer than the old phone, and the excellent display occupies the full area of the screen. The Hasselblad camera has a multitude of features, which I haven't exploited yet, including "Pro", "Slo-Mo" and "Time Lapse". The photos I have taken so far are of excellent quality. The 8GB of RAM can be expanded by a further 5GB, by using some of the 128GB of storage, should you need it. I'm very satisfied with the performance of the "10 Pro 5G", and it's great for making phone calls and sending texts too.

Man merkt ihm nicht an, dass es eigentlich ein sehr gro√ües Smartphone ist. Display: Hier liefert derzeit eigentlich jedes Flagship voll ab, auch das Oneplus. Ich finde das iPhone ist etwas realit√§tsnaher kalibriert, das Oneplus wirkt da etwas bunter.. Geschmackssache. review: De Oppo Reno 8 Pro springt qua kleur meteen al in het oog. Met een gladde body ligt hij lekker in de hand. De telefoon is soepel, snel en gaat lang mee met zijn batterij. Met de meegeleverde 80-watt lader is je toestel in een halfuur alweer bijna helemaal vol. Al met al prettig in gebruik! Het scherm: Met een scherm van 6,7" is het een flink toestel. Door de dunne randen om het scherm is de telefoon zelf niet formaatje koelkast. Het scherm is ontzettend helder met een mooie kleurweergave. Gebruik: In gebruik is de telefoon erg prettig. Door de 12GB RAM is de telefoon razendsnel en is wisselen tussen apps vloeiend en gaat het werken razendsnel. De processor had wellicht wat beter kunnen zijn voor deze prijs, maar bij normaal gebruik zul je hier weinig van merken. Camera's: De camera's vallen meteen op. De hele cameramodule neemt haast een kwart van de achterkant in beslag. Desondanks valt de kwaliteit van de foto's tot nu toe enigszins tegen. In de autofocus is een duidelijke AI verbetering te zien, waardoor het wellicht niet aan de hardware ligt, maar meer aan de software. Hierin hoop ik meer te ontdekken om optimaal gebruik te kunnen maken van de camera's. De selfiecam is erg goed, gedetailleerd en scherp terwijl het maar een klein deel van het scherm inneemt. Connectiviteit: De telefoon is 5G-ready, maar helaas heb ik daar geen gebruik van gemaakt. Afgezien daarvan is hij hartstikke snel, zowel op WiFi als 4G. De Bluetooth verbinding werkt prima met draadloze oortjes en door de UI kun je makkelijk wisselen tussen output via de speakers of via Bluetooth. NFC werkt snel! Geluid: Door het stereogeluid is het mogelijk om ook multiplayergames waarin directioneel geluid een rol speelt te spelen zonder koptelefoon. Het volume van de speakers is goed en het geluid dat eruit komt is zo goed als je van een smartphone mag verwachten. Al met al is de Oppo Reno 8 Pro een snelle telefoon met een prachtig scherm. De Oppo UI is vlot zonder al te veel onzinnige dingen.Less

review: Enkele weken heb ik de OPPO Reno 8 Pro mogen testen. Het is een mooi toestel om te zien, een prachtige vormgeving en sprekende kleur. De camera's op de achterzijde zijn geplaatst in een verdikking op de telefoon. De kleur en vorm geven de telefoon een unieke look. Houd er wel rekening mee dat er weinig hoesjes beschikbaar zijn voor dit model mocht je dit belangrijk vinden. De eerste keer gebruik begint natuurlijk met de installatie, dit gaat vlot en spreekt voor zich, net als het besturingssysteem als je Android al gewend bent. De systeem is snel en heeft tot nu toe nog geen mankementen laten zien. De accu gaat lang mee en is snel opgeladen. Voor mij kon hij zo'n twee dagen redelijk intensief gebruik aan. Wanneer je snel de deur uit moet is het snelladen ideaal, in zo'n 15 minuten is hij genoeg opgeladen voor bijna een dag gebruik. Het AMOLED scherm en geluid zijn grote pluspunten van de telefoon. Beiden zijn kraakhelder. Het geluid komt vanuit zowel de bovenzijde van de telefoon als de onderzijde. Zowel bij muziek als bij films/series is dit een echte meerwaarde. De camera is wat mij nieuwsgierig maakte naar deze telefoon. Na het testen kan ik zeggen dat hij niet tegen valt. Ook in beweging kan hij dieren en kinderen scherp vastleggen. Zelfs in de schemer/in het donker valt de camera niet tegen. De 4K ultra night video werkt boven verwachting goed. Enige punt van kritiek zou zijn dat het inzoomen op een object wat wat verder verwijderd is, een minder scherp beeld geeft. Zoals een vogel op zo'n drie meter afstand, deze kun je niet scherp op beeld krijgen. Samengevat is het een mooi toestel die goed presteert. Wat mij betreft een aanrader.Less

review: Heb de telefoon nu een paar weken en ben positief verrast. Ter info ik gebruik al jaren een Iphone, vanaf de 4S. Het is een grote telefoon maar hij ligt lekker in de hand, het ook wil ook wat en dat krijg je ook bij deze Oppo, ik vind hem er heel strak uitzien. Het eerste wat opvalt in gebruik is de knop rechts waarmee je de telefoon vergrendelt, hij zit net iets lager dan wat ik gewend ben en dit is erg prettig, op de juist hoogte zeg maar, zeker als je kleinere handen hebt ga je dit merken. De telefoon kwam vrijwel leeg aan dus na even spelen moest hij aan de lader. Ik denk dat we allemaal aan een uurtje laden wel gewend zijn om hem weer op niveau te krijgen. Ultra fast laden staat er in het schem als ik hem aansluit, nou ben benieuwd denk ik. Ik blijf even staan kijken en zie gewoon de procenten omhoog lopen. Na 15 min kom ik terug en hij is vol. Wow. Benieuwd hoe lang de accu dan meegaat. Na 3 dagen hoef ik hem pas weer op te laden bijkt. Heb veel zitten spelen met alle instellingen, foto's gemaakt, etc. en zelfs 6 uur achter elkaar muziek af laten spelen. Ook dit is echt wel een hele vooruitgang. Ik gebruik normaal 2 telefoons, 1 zakelijk en 1 prive, dankzij de dubbele SIM functie is dit verleden tijd. Dan de snelheid van de telefoon. Een app installeren gaat heel snel, knipperen en geinstalleerd. Dan het deel waar ik "bang"voor was, kan ik wennen aan een Android want de indeling zal wel anders zijn en en en. Na een beetje spelen lijkt de indeling op mijn vertrouwde telefoon. Ook de instellingen zijn best wel vanzelfsprekend zou ik eigenlijk zeggen. Ja er zitten dingen bij die ik niet ken maar het is zeker eenvoudiger dan gedacht. Foto's en filmen, 1 van de dingen die de meeste mensen toch veel doen. Wat opvalt is in donkere situaties, dag en nacht verschil want het lijkt wel dag. De beoordeling van mijn zoon van 14: "mag ik hem hebben", hij wil dus zijn XR er voor inruilen. Dit zegt wellicht meer dan mijn mening maar ook ik ben zeer positief over deze Oppo.Less

review: Zodra je het doosje opent lacht de telefoon je tegemoet. De telefoon heeft een nette en professionele uitstraling. En eenmaal uitgepakt en geinstalleerd, wat overigens vrij simpel gaat als je bijvoorbeeld al een andere android telefoon gewend was, ga je toch de eerste voor de hand liggende features testen. Laden gaat echt heel snel en de telefoon heeft een lange gebruiksduur. 48 uur met intensief gebruik redt ie niet. Maar klokje 2x rond is appeltje eitje. En dan leg je hem aan de lader en binnen 30 minuten laadt ie van 15% zo naar vol. Dan de camera; die is ook erg goed, scherp en helder. Foto's van mensen op afstand komen er prima op. Dan de muziek; er zit een heel helder speakertje ingebouwd. Die zorgt er voor dat je niet naar "blik-geluid" luistert maar muziek zoals het moet wezen. Filmpjes en clips zijn ook van prima kwaliteit. Is er niets negatiefs te melden? Ja 1 ding. Het toestel is zonder hoesje erg glad. Hij blijft niet zomaar op je been liggen maar glijdt zo ineens naar links of rechts. Een hoesje zou dus echt een aanrader zijn.Less

De batterijduur is lang, eenmaal opgeladen en bij normaal tot intensief gebruik kan je telefoon ongeveer 2 dagen meegaan. Ik ben erg benieuwd hoe ik dit toestel over enkele maanden zal beoordelen, maar voor nu een en al lof voor Oppo!

review:
I've only had my DOOGEE V20 for 5 days, but I'm already in love!
I was prepared for the extra weight of it's big battery because the reverse charging feature was worth it to me. I can't say I'm impressed with how long the charge lasts, though, but I do use my phone online quite a bit as well as for calls & messages.
I'm especially pleased with the desktop. The shortcuts to frequently used numbers and apps are big enough to use at night without my glasses, were easy to set up & so convenient.
I haven't used my camera or night vision yet, but I am a bit disappointed with the screenshot function, which I use a lot. Pressing the power & volume down buttons, which are next to each other, at the same time is difficult for small hands like mine. I have to reach over with my left hand in order to press the buttons separately using both hands. It would be much easier to use buttons on opposite sides of the phone so you can press with your thumb on the left while pressing with a finger on the right side.
I went thru 4 standard phones in 3 years since I'm clumsy due to strokes & epilepsy, but my 1st rugged phone, a Galaxy S7 Active, even without a screen protector or case, lasted 5 years before it got glitchy- I'm taking those precautions with this one. 
I shopped around and bought this DOOGEE V20 for about half the price of my Samsung and if it lasts half as long I'll still consider it $ well spent.Less

review: Fain telefon. Se mica repede, arata bine, se simte foarte solid si robust in mana. + camera cu infrarosu este super, chiar se vede foarte bine, atat ca si claritate, cat si ca distanta + nu are o gramada de aplicatii inutile si imposibil de dezinstalat, cum includ alti producatori + ecranul secundar de pe spatele telefonului este frumos si util - luati in calcul dimensiunile si greutatea acestui telefon (pt mine nu e un minus, am mai avut astfel de telefoane si stiam in ce ma bag :D) - nu imi place ca nu imi arata cat % din baterie a fost consumat de fiecare aplicatie (alte tel. arata) - nu am niciun update disponibil (de sistem, sau de securitate) - unele sunt din iulie 2022.. din pacate chestia asta e destul de frecventa la producatori: vand un tel si apoi uita de el. Una peste alta eu sunt multumit de el si il recomand oricui are o viata activa. Am avut un tel similar in trecut si m-a tinut 4 ani, folosindu-l intens. Numai cuite nu am batut cu el, deci astfel de telefoane sunt o investitie buna.Less

review: I bought the Apple iPhone 11 64GB and it was brand new, unused, in perfect condition. It came with a USB to lightning charging cable. It's locked to the carrier of course, but if you maintain 2 months of continuous cellphone service, it will unlock (depending on what carrier you have, and if the policies change or not). It includes the SIM card. Just pop the sim card inside the phone, in the sim card tray, turn on phone, log in with your Apple ID, and activate it online. After you activate online, you have to restart the phone, and it instantly works. It was easy to setup and to activate. This iPhone 11 is VERY fast and can run all the apps quickly, even including games. The iPhone has 2 cameras, the regular 1x, and an ultra-wide camera. Both cameras are clear, sharp, and colorful. It has night mode so the camera takes good photos in dim light if you hold the camera very steady. The camera flash can be turned on, off, or auto, and it's a very bright flash. The camera is super fast too, you can take photos as fast as you can press the shutter button. For 99 cents a month you can get 50GB more cloud storage from Apple to backup more photos online. IPhone 11 can work with Apple Pay for wireless payments at many stores. It doesn't have Mag Safe, but it does wirelessly charge just fine if you put a MagSafe charger directly under it. Battery life is good. Face ID unlock is super quick, and much better than fingerprint unlock for me. Face ID just always works. The phone's brightness is good, I set it to just over half brightness indoors, and it can be read easy enough outdoors on full brightness. FaceTime calls are a great thing when you want to video call, because most people use iPhone now. Podcasts are fun to listen to, and you can get podcasts on almost any subject. iPhone includes great free software preloaded, like GarageBand for making music, iMovie for making videos, Numbers, Keynote, and Pages. The included Home app works with your smart devices and smart lightbulbs for home automation. Apple Books app has lots of free books on there if you like reading on your phone. The fitness app is perfect for tracking your steps and workouts. The "Siri" voice assistant is useful for setting alarms, asking questions, setting timers, getting the weather, but is not quite as smart as the Google assistant. If you want to use Google, you can download their app, and Google voice assistant works from within the app when you click on the microphone. All in all, this is the BEST smartphone you can get right now at this price point, especially if you are already in the Apple and Mac computer ecosystem. If you have a MacBook, iPhone is perfect with it. Your texts show up on your MacBook, and everything else links, like your photos, notes, emails, podcasts, files.Less

review: I really do like this phone, and the Straight Talk Customer Service was very helpful, which is why I gave this 3 stars. However, it was a pain to get it going. First, I did not realize Apple doesn't send a way to charge this phone. They send a charger, but nothing to plug it into, like a wall adapter. When I got the phone, I was broke and having to quarantine, so it was another week before I could go to the store to purchase something to help charge the phone, which meant I could barely use it for the first week. Also, I almost threw away the activation and SIM card because they blended in so much with packaging. I was looking for a big red card and instead it was in a small gray envelope attached to the plastic wrap. I only found it a week later after I got a charger, because thankfully I saved all the packaging. Then the phone still would not activate, and I had to spend all weekend getting this fixed. Thankfully, I was able to chat with Straight Talk customer service, and they were really helpful. It turned out after spending all day today trying to get this fixed that it needed to run an update for about 30 minutes before working right. I can say now I like a lot about this phone, like the camera, having more space, and the sound quality. I had to buy wireless earbuds, but I am able to use some $25 Skull Candy bluetooth ones instead of buying higher dollar Apple ones. I'm also glad to see Spotify is compatible, because that is the main app I use. I think I will love my phone now that I can finally use it, but it has taken about two weeks of worry trying to get to this point.Less

review: This phone is fast, it‚Äôs simple, and it‚Äôs easy, much like previous iPhones. I admit the lack of home button scared me at first, as I had previously only owned an iPhone 8 and iPhone 6, however the transition is smooth and rather satisfying to swipe away the apps rather than click‚Ä¶ a feature I had not noticed before in previous makes. I admit when making this purchase I bought it for the camera, I had hopes of this amazing camera I could use for photography or simply to just take photos of day to day life and capture the exact beauty‚Ä¶ whilst this camera does come with noticeable improvements from previous iPhones, it isn‚Äôt amazing. I would have wanted something more from a camera that had been the main focus of the phone. Despite this, the camera is still good! The features to expand photos to get more of the scenery in is amazing, the way it makes dark photos lighter, or even the detail you can capture in video, especially with higher settings. Something I had noticed that I wish this phone had, is fingerprint recognition. Whilst yes, the face recognition is cool, there are times where, it simply doesn‚Äôt recognise my face, or I‚Äôm wearing a mask so I can‚Äôt use it, or I‚Äôm laying down in the dark cuddled up in my blanket, face smooshed to unrecognisable proportions‚Ä¶ and those times I have to type in my passcode just to see my notifications in further detail because the phone cannot see me. I have noticed that android phones still have the finger print recognition, despite the lack of a home button, and as well as face recognition. This is something Apple must think about in its upcoming products. I miss the simplicity of fingerprint recognition and it‚Äôs the one thing this phone is lacking. As for battery life. It isn‚Äôt amazing, but it isn‚Äôt as bad as previous generations. There is still a lot of work to do when it comes to battery life, especially when comparing my iPhone to my boyfriends android, his can last days where as mine is lucky to last the same day, with both of us using our phones just as much as each other. As for the waterproof features‚Ä¶ yes this phone is waterproof, though even getting water inside the charging port will prevent you from charging. This feature helps to protect your phone from damage caused from water meeting electricity in the charger needed to charge your phone‚Ä¶ you are also given the option to force a charge if it is an emergency and are warned of the risks. The best option for this is to having a charging pad, rather than a charging cable‚Ä¶ though it isn‚Äôt exactly something I would have wished for a ‚Äúwaterproof‚Äù product to have. I think the next step is to find a more water friendly way of charging without there needing to be a risk warning at all, yet still being as handy as the lead charger, in which you can still pick up your phone.Less

review: Despite this model being released in 2019 its still a very capable phone. The dual cameras on the back capture great quality photos even in poorer light conditions. The phone is very responsive even running the newest version of the iOS 16 software. The screen quality is crisp, clear, bright and responsive as you would expect even when i compare this to newer models. review: After using this phone every day for nearly a year and a half I‚Äôve come to form my own take on this device. At first glance the Iphone 11 is a large yet slim looking device, much larger than my previous phone the Iphone 8. At first, I thought this would allow the phone to be more vulnerable to getting damaged when dropped although even when in a basic case with no screen protector the phone as survived every drop. For its larger size the phone is light weight and able to fit comfortably in my clothes pockets. A positive to this phone is that it is larger, I am a little bit on the taller side so the phone is able to fit comfortably in my hands, it‚Äôs nice to watch videos on and I had no problem adjusting quickly from the smaller size of the Iphone 8 to the size of the Iphone 11. This might be a con for shorter people, women and children might not be able to fit it as easily into their hands or clothing‚Äôs pockets. The battery life is outstanding with the Iphone 11 being fitted with the newer batteries, I‚Äôm able to go about 8/9 hours with heavy usage and about 15 hours on a regular day of being active with work or school with light to moderate usage. Maybe you forgot to plug your phone in the night before (I know we have all been there) or you‚Äôre just caught at a bad time and need a little extra charge, 20-30 minutes of charging is worth a few more hours of screen time if you need it. Another addition is the new ultrawide lens camera which allows you to capture more of the environment, creating more opportunities to capture even more of a crisp clear image with the amazing camera. Videos are also of amazing making it very easy for me to film better quality (4k 60fps) videos while doing various physically intense activities like long boarding or running making it very easy for anyone to get into videography or photography. The speakers are another thing to note having the ability to play a loud music in a quite room making it enjoyable listen to outside or to blast music while in the shower. As for the IOS it is as good as its ever been still loading applications at super-fast speeds making everything you do on the phone like Face ID, watching Netflix or using a heavy app as smooth as butter. Overall, I have no complaints for this phone, it crosses everything off my list of things I want and need in a phone and goes above and beyond. This phone will easily last me years to come and I‚Äôm excited as well as satisfied.Less

review: I had reservations about switching to iPhone as I‚Äôve been an Android user for the past 10 years or more. The reservations I had were about the battery life, iOS, being locked to the apple store and the lcd screen on this phone. The specs on paper are nothing to write home about and if it was an Android I would have probably bypassed this phone. So glad I didn‚Äôt. 1. The battery life is amazing, I‚Äôm a moderate user, calls, banking, messages, watching YouTube and using sat nav. By the end of a day I still have around 40-50% battery left which I never got on my Android. My Android phone had a 4500mah battery and this one I think is 3400, I‚Äôm not sure what wizardry they have under the hood but it‚Äôs incredibly efficient without compromising on performance. The Apple store has all the apps I was using with Android and all apps work smoothly and seamlessly. My Android phone was a super amoled compared to this lcd the Android screen is better but marginally. The Liquid Retina display on this thing is amazing, and yes the blacks are not as deep as an amoled but the difference is very little, I was so pleasantly surprised. Face unlock is super responsive. The iOS does take some getting used to but I adjusted very quickly to it. Only negative points were remembering all the passwords to the apps, downloading my CDs onto the iPhone which I watched a YouTube video and managed and having to buy a usb adaptor so I could charge the phone. Apart from these minor gripes I‚Äôm so glad I switched this really is a well built and quality phone. Yes you can get a very decent mid range Android with better specs but this will blow it out of the water. It took me ages to take the plunge but do not regret it one bit. Furthermore, got this with a further 10% cash back from Very. Win win.Less

review: What can I say. It's a great phone, and I have no complaints. It makes calls, it sends texts. review: I really do like this phone, and the Straight Talk Customer Service was very helpful, which is why I gave this 3 stars. However, it was a pain to get it going. First, I did not realize Apple doesn't send a way to charge this phone. They send a charger, but nothing to plug it into, like a wall adapter. When I got the phone, I was broke and having to quarantine, so it was another week before I could go to the store to purchase something to help charge the phone, which meant I could barely use it for the first week. Also, I almost threw away the activation and SIM card because they blended in so much with packaging. I was looking for a big red card and instead it was in a small gray envelope attached to the plastic wrap. I only found it a week later after I got a charger, because thankfully I saved all the packaging. Then the phone still would not activate, and I had to spend all weekend getting this fixed. Thankfully, I was able to chat with Straight Talk customer service, and they were really helpful. It turned out after spending all day today trying to get this fixed that it needed to run an update for about 30 minutes before working right. I can say now I like a lot about this phone, like the camera, having more space, and the sound quality. I had to buy wireless earbuds, but I am able to use some $25 Skull Candy bluetooth ones instead of buying higher dollar Apple ones. I'm also glad to see Spotify is compatible, because that is the main app I use. I think I will love my phone now that I can finally use it, but it has taken about two weeks of worry trying to get to this point.Less

Negatives: Apple stitch up their software so tight it's often hard to use 3rd party hardware, and the absence of any facility to increase onboard storage capacity (eg SD card as with Samsung et al) can be frustrating as you end up paying a lot more if you want anything more than what the basic model offers. review: The problem that you have when you buy the phone online at walmart.com. They don't tell you that you have 14 days to return or exchange it. I brought 2 iPhone 11 on black friday for Christmas for my kids. I tried to activate them, but I couldn't on Christmas Eve. That's because walmart.com doesn't scan the serial number and the IMEI bar code before you get it. That's makes it look like no one brought the phone so it seems stolen to the carrier. You have to go to a Walmart store in customer service and show them proof on your online receipt along with your phones. They have to scan both the serial number and the IMEI bar codes to activate them by price overriding to 0 dollars and then call straight talk to handle the rest. Problem Solved.

review: In recent years, a new line of iPhones coming along has become an annual event. 2019 was no different as Apple introduced the iPhone 11 line of products. Priced at $699 for the standard 64 gb iPhone 11 model, is it really worth the upgrade from 2018‚Äôs XR? The short answer is yes, absolutely. Even as Apple‚Äôs ‚Äúbudget‚Äù model in their current generation lineup, this device packs a lot into its frame comparable in size to an iPhone 8 Plus. When compared to the XR, the iPhone 11 may not seem all that different on the outside, but it‚Äôs the internals of the device where this product far outshines it predecessor. The body of the phone is almost identical with the same sized notch in the identical 6.1‚Äù Liquid Retina display, same button placements on the sides, and same bezels surrounding the screen. The only identifiable difference is the slight relocation of the signature Apple logo and the brand new double camera assortment. This dual camera takes the iPhone 11 to an entirely new high as far as image quality and clarity goes. Image stabilization and clarity are both incredible on iPhone 11, made possible by these two cameras working in tandem. These cameras also now offer the flash-free night mode enabling users to take great pictures in low light situations without employing the use of the flash. Moving from the cameras on the back to the camera on the front, Apple gave this camera that has seen a massive jump in use in recent years an even more impressive overhauling than the ones on the back. The iPhone 11 is packing a 12 megapixel camera in the front of the device capable of shooting video in 4K resolution at 60 FPS. For comparison, the XR‚Äôs front facing camera was a 7 megapixel camera only capable of 60 FPS in 1080p. With the new larger battery contained in the iPhone 11, you‚Äôll get around an extra hour or two of extra life on each charge depending on what you use your phone for and how heavy your use is. Overall, the standard iPhone 11 is an excellent phone for all types of users and a huge step up from the iPhone XR for only $100 extra. $699 for an iPhone 11 easily beats out $599 for a XR in every category. If you are looking for a great Apple phone without spending over a grand for a bunch of features most average users will never utilize, the iPhone 11 is a great choice. Apple knocked it out of the park with this release.Less

review: As a die-hard android fan for many years, this was the first iPhone that has the spotlight as my daily driver. I was looking for a cheaper iPhone that would still give me the newest iOS has to offer. After extensive hunting I finally got my hands on the 7, and I must say Im impressed. Despite having not the greatest specs and being around 3 or 4 years old now, Apple still gives it care, equipping it with the newest iOS and keeping it up to date. iMessage is INFINITELY better than any default messaging service android has currently (fix your s*** Android) and many of the features I fell in love with in my Samsung are on my iPhone. As far as hardware goes, the bezels are nowhere near as bothersome as I originally thought. I used to have an s8, so swallowing a 5.8 inch screen with seemingly giant bezels was hard. But after using it for about a day, I got used to it quickly. The hardware mute switch is one of my favorite things about the iPhone, something I actually wish android took from Apple for a long time. Camera quality is pretty good, as long as youre in ideal lighting. Dont go thinking youll get crystal clear night time shots and youll be fine. Now for a few complaints, starting with one Im sure youre familiar with: battery life. The iPhone 7 has a mediocre battery atbest, dropping (from 100%) to about 30-40% on light usage, 15-25% on medium usage, and 2-14% on heavy usage (not including games- COD Mobile and PUBG Mobile kill this phone). I would recommend getting a modified battery if possible (like the ExCap from MobileSentrix). A few other minor things are that the phone can get warm on medium usage and its small form factor can be a little annoying for doing things like playing games (an easy fix is to buy the 7 plus). Obviously this phone is infamous for starting the absurd trend of removing the 3.5mm headphone jack on the bottom, which I will admit I still hate a lot after having this phone for about a month now. But if you get yourself a pair of bluetooth earbuds you should be okay. Its not the end of the world. My final gripe is that there is no wireless charging support. I really miss not being able to charge my phone wirelessly but it is not a huge deal. Other than those minor things, I would 100% recommend this phone, especially to people who are new to Apple like myself. Its a great, cheap way to get introduced to the Apple community. Solid 8/10Less

review: Pros: The iPhone 11. It‚Äôs the perfect phone really, and at a "decent price‚Äù for a 256 gig phone. I upgraded from an iPhone 6 to this iPhone 11- and the difference is night and day (similar speed performance from iPhone 3GS (remember them?) to iPhone 6). Looking at these new phones, and with the ever increase in technology, the word ‚Äúimpossible ‚Äú should be used with caution- if at all, in what can be achieved from a device that fits snuggly in your pocket. review: I bought my first iPhone (6s) about 6 years ago. I loved everything about it, mainly the pretty rose gold colour but also how it spoke to my iPad and subsequently my iMac. When the battery seemed to look as if it was failing I removed some software which helped a little, I considered sending it off to have a new battery. Most people seem amazed that my old phone had lasted so long so I opted to replace it with the new iPhone 11 128Gb. I've had the new phone about two weeks now. Of course once I removed the sim from my old phone the battery charge improved! I am not great at taking photos or videos so chose this model over the pro. I was aware the battery charge was not fantastic but I am so disappointed to have to be constantly recharging it, and it is slow to charge. I am not a heavy user, a few texts, shopping list etc. It is not the computer in my pocket it is for the younger generation, how frustrating must it be for someone using it for work? And, of course it is not anywhere as pretty as my old phone! However, I am very pleased with Face ID which is so quick and so much better than I believed it would be. The phone is slightly larger than the 6s which helps my ageing eyes. I wish the icon sizes could be made a little larger, apparently it's not a feature on this model. I also cannot use my old headphones unless I buy a jack or dongle because the new headphones plug into the charging port, which could be a problem for heavy users who need to charge the phone more frequently. I know I'm probably not a typical user and I am still finding my way around the phone but I just don't love it the way I did my 6s.Less

review: Went from 8 to 11 and I really like it. Feels faster than an already fast phone. In some apps you can really see the improved graphics even the XR's A12 would have brought, but I like the A13 processor in the iPhone 11 series for the improvements on the low power cores that it brings. My daily routine that would get me 4 and a half to five hours now only takes me down to 60% battery. The increase in RAM from my iPhone 8's 2GB to the 11's 4GB also sees fewer of my apps being closed in the background while I switch between tasks. I skipped the X-series because I wasn't too sold on the redesign but I honestly don't notice it day-to-day. The gestures took no time at all getting used to while the notch doesn't really get in the way of much, aside from a few games I tested for performance. I did notice the screen quality difference at a side-by-side in an ATT store, but it's still a really good LCD, albeit a weird resolution that doesn't quite want to properly fit large content at times. I only wish it was the size of the Pro with that slightly smaller screen size of 5.8" to the 11's 6.06". Some situations require two hands or trading a sure grip for one that could easily slip but the phone never feels bulky or unwieldy. I'd recommend a case or skin for the back, though. It can be very slippery. I never intended to trade my iPhone 8 so soon, but the price for performance, coupled with the improvements of the iPhone 11's processor, was too good to pass up.Less

review: I've had an iPhone 7 for over 2 years through Version and never had any screen cracking or significant software issues. Yes, the lightening port broke on my first phone (but was replaced for free) and I went through multiple cases. I only replaced it due to the end of life issues of the phone. Now for the iPhone 11, it was a nice upgrade in terms of larger battery life and some newer iOS features. The screen size is bigger than I liked but not a deal breaker. What I really am upset about is, even with an elevated case, I woke up this morning to a hairline crack going through my screen and a "arrow" crack around the housing near the camera lenses. I did not drop my phone in the last 24 hours or at all since acquiring this phone (early December) yet somehow these showed up. I am now stuck paying extra every month for a broken phone that will likely continue to break over the next two years. I have no real ability to replace this phone without having to pay a restocking fee or other fees for something outside my control. What am I supposed to do, keep the phone in 5 layers of bubble wrap at all times? This is a great example of a company (Apple) reducing the quality of their products year to year. Avoid this phone.Less

When I use my wireless transfer from my camera to my phone I have to have the app open at all times, with my Note 9 I could have 5 apps open and still transfer in the background plus it didn't overheat and I could use 4K on YouTube and videos. review: First of all, let's be clear, I absolutely love to research any new big ticket [or small ticket] item before I purchase it. My Sony phone died almost 3 months ago, and that's when I started researching for a new phone. I hav always been an Andriod purchaser so the switch to an iPhone was a big deal for me. I researched C-Net, the Apple website and YouTube for any and all product information I could find. That took an enitre month. Once satified, I concentrated on my main concerns which were quality of the product, price and battery life and choosing the iPhone that was right for me. I read reveiw after review, compared prices once I chose the iPhone I wanted [the iPhone 11, 64 GB, Purple, just under $850.00 with 2-year insurance plan] and then compared prices on various sites. I finally made my purchase in April. I must say that I am completed satisfied with the phone. It paired perfectely with my iPad and Dell laptop. I also signed up for a free one year trial on Apple TV. The battery life is amazing! I followed the advise of several YouTube videos as to how to achieve maximum battery life by making several adjustments in the settings. My battery has lasted up to 3 entire days without a recharge. I love it. I look forward to my next iPhone purchase when the new iPhone 12 arrives. The 11 will go to my daughter. Great phone. Great price.Less

review: I have upgraded from my trusty iPhone 6 which I had for a long time, and the iPhone 11 is a revelation. It's lovely and fast, and has a very nice size and quality screen. While I thought I might miss the fingerprint ID, the face recognition is brilliant (and doesn't annoyingly keep coming on by itself when someone just goes near it, like some Androids). The camera is excellent, and I love the new superwide angle lens. I deliberated for some time whether to get the Pro, which has the telephoto lens, but am glad I didn't, as it's quite a lot more expensive and the screen is smaller. I am pleased I went for the 128GB version, it fits all my Apple Lossless music on the device, as well as loads of pictures (Apple Photos seems the best for organising this). When getting the phone I decided to get also the Belkin Qi 5W wireless charger and Apple Earpods (wireless ones). I've been similarly massively impressed by these as well, which make me finally start using Siri and enjoying it. ("Siri, text this message to so-and-so...). Overall - amazing, just get one. Excellent service from John Lewis, fast and quality delivery as usual.Less

review:
I loved the camera. But that doesn't cancel out the overwhelming negative that this thing has a glass jaw! It can't take a hit. If your toddler drops it onto your linoleum floor, your phone is a gunner. At least it's wholeness. I dropped mine after about a month or so after my old phone was stolen. It wasn't even a s and I dropped that thing so many times but only a few times did it get damaged. Let's be clear, my phone is in my hand most every single day most of the day. They didn't have a case at the Walmart i bought it from. And I also had some money trouble so I used my case money on something more needed at the time. 

Anywho, first drop was on smooth concrete from waist high and I'm 5' 7" so that was less than a 3 foot drop. Shattered the corner. The latter 3 times is a blur but each time was from a low height. I remember one I was sitting in the car with my phone in my lap and forgot it was there so when I got out I kinda brought it with me. It kerplunked onto blacktop and I can't remember if it broke the camera glass or if it pinched the front screen. But the pinched screen has made it almost worthless. It constantly pulls down the quick access screen. It also goes crazy constantly. Most times I can't even complete a Google search. It'll bounce to another screen. Be it from the settings or sometimes random websites and other problems. It's drove me to cuss. I would get it fixed but it's 400+ to fix the screen crack. Not the camera protector glass, the shattered corner or another chip in the other side. I would throw the thing through the wall but I have 30 more months to pay on the damn thing. Biggest freaking ripoff of a phone I ever encountered. Trading the sucker for a s22 with hopes It'll be a better phone. Gorilla glass 6 is FATALY FLAWED. It isn't even a tiny monkey. You could break it dropping it into a paper bag.

If Samsung stood for quality products and customer satisfaction they would recall these and factory fix them. Or offer full pay off credit towards a later model. Or a even swap.

Samsung S22 ultra 5g SUCKS and so does Gorilla Glass 6.Less

review: The Samsung S20 Ultra is a high-end smartphone with a large display, it includes five cameras, and a massive battery (5,000mAh) . It's a powerful device that's great for gaming and multitasking, but it's also quite expensive for the performance. The display is bright and sharp, and the five cameras allow you to take great photos and videos. The battery life is excellent, and the phone can even charge other devices wirelessly. The only downside is the price tag lime I said in the first paragraph. The S20 Ultra has a powerful camera system. The main camera is a 108 MP sensor with an optical image stabilization. It is capable of shooting 8K video and has a 100x digital zoom which is a very amazing feature to use when you are trying to read something very far away. The secondary camera is a 48 MP sensor. It is also capable of shooting 8K video, but it takes up alot of space. The camera system is very impressive and is capable of taking great photos and videos. The 100x digital zoom is also a great feature, although it is not always accurate. The time-of-flight sensor is a nice addition, but it is not very useful in most situations. Overall, the Samsung S20 Ultra is a great smartphone with an excellent camera system. If you are looking for a high-end smartphone with a great camera, the S20 Ultra is a great option.Less

review: I've had this phone for about 2 years now. A friend more or less gifted it to me as I needed a better phone and service compared to what I had at the time. The phone itself in regards to its appearance is fine. In my opinion the camera is also fine but it could be better. Sometomes it randomly loses focus or has difficulty focusing. Some times image quality is blurry but 8/10 its usually okay. I like the large screen as well. My issues lie with my internet/data service. For whatever reason this phone LOVES to randomly disconnect and reconnect from data and wifi alike. Normally this issue last a few seconds and generally no real harm comes from it but it does still negatively affect me regularly in the form of lag, freezing and being forced to refresh a page or app. Furthermore the phone was alright until April 20th when a system update occurred and I'm not sure if it's coincidence or what, but now my phone keeps crashing VERY often. It's gotten to the point where I can't even use certain apps without crashes. I'm CONSTANTLY having to restart said apps. I'm really hoping it's temporary because if it's not I am concerned with whether or not I will continue remaining a customer for long. It's one thing to experience some mild issues but to have the phone practically unusable on a daily is quite excessive. When an app crashes and I'm prompted if I want to report the issue, even that service crashes making me unable to even report my issue. Lastly my GPS functions are weird. Not only is it frequently "weak" but also it gives semi frequent inaccurate data.. or it bounces me all over the place. Overall it's an okay phone, but in my option it's FAR from worth the price.Less

review: I have been using Galaxy phones for a considerable amount of years. Personally I can't fault them. review: I have waited  7 months to write a review so I can be precise about it. This device has a hard time connecting to the verizon internet without the help of wifi is my biggest complaint. My Droid Turbo 2 had the best camera ever. Even took senior pics with it.  I love the size of the Samsung Galaxy S20 5G. review:
A few years ago I switched from IPhone and never looked back. I've had several galaxy phones and watches and LOVED every one. I bought this phone specifically for the camera capabilities, ignoring the poor reviews stating focusing issues, and I feel so let down. review:
A few years ago I switched from IPhone and never looked back. I've had several galaxy phones and watches and LOVED every one. I bought this phone specifically for the camera capabilities, ignoring the poor reviews stating focusing issues, and I feel so let down. IT DOES NOT MATTER HOW FANTASTIC YOUR CAMERA IS IF IT CANNOT FOCUS ON THE SUBJECT OF THE PHOTO. The camera is slow to launch, slow to focus, and when it finally chooses a focal point a great deal of the surrounding image is blurry. Close up images of flowers, etc are near impossible to capture crisply. I can't even take a clear image of a two dimensional sheet of paper (very frustrating from a work perspective).
I've spent nearly a year messing with every setting and option I can think of to get around this massive flaw. From frequent updates to rebooting the camera settings, shooting in safe mode to ensure no interference from other apps. I've tried every pre set or manual option available and nothing has improved the camera's ability to focus. 
Now that some time has passed it seems one or two of the cameras have stopped working because I can only focus at great distances with much effort. My options are to replace with a refurbished which still leaves me with a substandard camera, upgrade and pay hundreds of dollars more with the possibility of the same issue, or go back to my s10+. For a $1200 purchase I expected more from a brand I trusted.Less

review: I mostly love this phone, but the camera left much to be desired against the hype of it. Yes, it is 108 MP. No, it absolutely will not compete with an entry-level 24MP DSLR in quality. I didn't have that expectation since phone camera sensors will never be able to compete with that class due simply to the physical size of the sensor, but I also didn't expect to have to switch back and forth in settings to get 108 MP, wide, or zoomed shots. I absolutely love the 4X optical zoom function and low-band 5G has been a nice upgrade even in my little rural town. The screen on this phone scratches VERY easily compared to other Samsungs I've owned in the past, so you'll want to keep that in mind if you regularly carry a pocket knife or something similar in hardness in there. Facebook and Instagram live streams seem to have found a way around the high quality camera and always use the one with the absolute lowest quality (this is not a setting you can adjust), so don't expect any miracles if you live stream from your phone on social media. Camera noise is tolerable in low light and actually looks pretty decent. Still, I wouldn't use it for even one second of serious video work.Less

review: I have owned many smartphones over the years and the Samsung Galaxy S20 Ultra has been the best of them by far. The camera quality is certainly unmatched by any other phone on the market today and the 100x zoom feature is practically unheard of in the US. The fingerprint and face scanners work very smoothly and the screen resolution is incredible. The size of this phone can sometimes make handling a little cumbersome but it is absolutely worth it in my opinion, after all, you aren't looking at this phone because you want a small one. The 5G capability has yet to be fully utilized but even so, this phone has incredibly fast processing times. All of these features are great in and of themselves but the best feature, in my opinion, is the battery life. If I use this phone for a total of about six hours per day, I can expect the battery to last about three days, which is awesome. Better yet though, if I only use this phone sparingly, for a total of about one or two hours per day, I can get at least five days worth of battery without having to charge it. I have used the newest iPhone models and I have to say the S20 Ultra absolutely blows them out of the water. Samsung has really outdone itself with this phone so if you are looking for a fast, advanced, and reliable phone, look no further!Less

review: From the day I started seeing pictures & descriptions of what the S20 Ultra may look/function like, I knew I wanted it. Then Samsung Unpacked was released and knew for sure I was going to be getting it. So, like with previous models, I signed up to be alerted to when I could pre-order it and did so ASAP. I've had it for a week and a half now and I'm in love with it. Though, it did take some time to get used to having all the buttons on the right side! I hit the volume button several times instead of the power/lock button but after a day or so, I got used to it. I'm so glad they got rid of the Bixby button unless you want the side button to open it. You can customize what the button does which is a nice new feature. I really love the camera. Love that they kept some of the features from the S10+ & it has the 108MP option as well as the zoom options. They now have more pre-set zoom options Now it has 2.0x, 4.0x, 10x, 30x, 100x zoom along with the previous pre-sets. Of course, you can manually adjust them.Also, like the night mode option for darker settings. Like the previous model, after an update, it has the "Link to Windows" so for example, if I want to send pictures to my computer, I don't have to email them to myself, send through BT, etc. I can have my phone connected to my computer, and all my pictures/videos, notifications, messages, calls, & phone home screen are all available. If you need to save a picture, just click "save as" and that's it. It's a convenient feature. You can set it so from the home screen, you can swipe down and rather then it opening the apps (just like swiping up), it will put the notification drop-down screen down. IMO it's much more practical than having swiping up & down opening apps. There are so many things to love about this phone and .I only named a few! I'm surprised there are only 2 color options this time especially since the other models have blue & pink available. The Cosmic Gray is beautiful though! Overall, I'm very happy with my decision to upgrade to the S20 Ultra!Less

review: My main interest in this Smartphone was initially because of the good reviews and recommendations on the camera quality. Particularly the low light performance. While the camera is excellent in daylight, Picture quality still dropped still drops off dramatically under very low light conditions such as a poorly lit nightclub or living room. The night mode is fun to use but you need to place it on a tripod or hold very still for decent results. Moving objects get blurry. It's useful as an inexpensive way to reveal scenes after dark and make them look aesthetically pleasing but don't expect great detail.

review: I love the last couple galaxy phones. They have really done great and had excellent cameras. This one was right on track for a great camera as well but there are a couple bugs. The auto-focus has been taking a couple attempts before getting it right and anything at close distance is not an option. The part where it takes a bit to find what you are looking at can probably be remedied with a software update but the other thing that unfortunately I bet is hardware related is that depth range of the focus. It's below what I would expect out of such a great camera. Only what it focuses on will pick up clear, anything just slightly farther or closer will start to blur quickly. Anything that has a little bit of length to it gets blurry at some point. If you focus on the part closer, it will blur the back of it. I put a part on a table and took a picture of it and the front looks fantastic but the back of the part quickly turns blurry. I even tried to get it to focus in the middle but there was no way of getting a clear picture of a part that was just a little long. See attached photo. Other than those small focus related issues, its a great camera and an excellent phone with lots of power and decent battery life. I love it.Less

review: The battery life is a drastic change compared to my Samsung 9 plus. Playing with the camera, I find myself in a love hate relationship because it keeps blurring and refocusing on me and its a little aggravating to deal with. I'm an avid "Duo" user which is Samsung's version of "FaceTime" on iPhone. And Duo-ing with someone who has an S10 plus, it appears that they carried over the low light capabilitiy and also added a few exclusive features such as AR Avatar, wide angle, and self portrait. You can also use these features in conjunction with one another. The camera is the selling feature of this phone and while I struggle using it a bit-- keep in mind that I would still rate myself as a novice user on this camera feature. The only downfall i see on this phone is not being able to have the best of both when having 120 hz refresh rate. But if you can sacrifice the 120 hz refresh rate for a 4k resolution, it's still a great phone. Overall this being a great phone, I am giving this 4 stars just because not only did they make this 120 hz refresh rate a selling point but didn't mention the downgrade in screen resolution. I'll try and update this review as I keep using this phone.Less

review: The Galaxy S20Ultra is for mobile owners with no compromises. Personally, after replacing the S10, I'm the happiest with the 120Hz display and the 45W supercharger. These are new features that I use with great pleasure on a daily basis. The 5000mAh battery does a fair job too, even with the 120Hz mode on. Naturally, the power of the 100, zoom and the 108MP capabilities were also pros when considering replacing the old S10, although in home confinement for 6 months I have not yet been able to fully utilize them. The USB 3.2 connector of my Samsung S20 Ultra has inspired me to upgrade my PC with an extension card to accommodate 20GB/s file transfer which is extremely useful when downloading 8k or 4k videos, 108MP photos and RAW files. review: Has a lot of cool features, but the camera is the WORST for up close photos. I've tried countless settings and have yet to get a nice crisp picture when I zoom in. My old phone took way better zoom pics than this Samsung. For the price, I'm EXTREMELY disappointed. If you're planning on using it for regular family or landscape pics it's fine, but for zoom in, all you get is blur. Since the in-store phones were locked down with a 2 inch long wire tethered to them, it was impossible to actually try out the camera so I took the sales rep's opinion of it at face value....perhaps I wasn't clear enough in my camera requirements. Also, this thing has quite a bit of weight to it and not ideal for when playing games. I'm an older woman and my wrist and hand actually starts to ache if I play for longer than 10 minutes. Someone younger probably wouldn't have any issues with this, but thought worth a mention. review: Have to say initially I was mystified by the Android OS for the 1st few hours. As a life long iPhone user I thought the change to Android was going to be tough, but I was wrong. I thought the phone had a dead pixel which was only noticeable when making phone calls, I was ready to exchange the phone. I did a quick google search and it said this isn't a dead pixel but a proximity sensor, something I believe Samsung should highlight as I text my friends saying I had a brand new phone with a dead pixel, thankfully it wasn't. Lastly, I would like to say the transfer of data was seamless. Just plug in your old device into your new one and around 45mins later everything has transferred over. Only thing that didn't move over was the media files in my Whatsapp but that's not a big deal.Less

review: Best phone I've ever owned. I upgrade from a Note 9, this phone is a tiny bit smaller, but has a bigger screen.. review: Product is as advertised. Gently used. No scratches or cracks. Reasonable price, for a used 2-3 month old flagship phone. Battery life is very good, about the same as my S10+. Although some have complained about camera focus issues, I have not experienced any real problems. As for the negatives, the claimed x100 is a joke. It's really good up to x20, maybe x30. I knew that from several reviews. But x20 is much better than my previous camera. It has been great for shooting pictures and video of wildlife. The addition of the Pro Video functionality is a big plus. Screen quality, resolution, brightness, refresh rate, etc. is about as good as it gets. I notice 120 Hz refresh is smoother, and I switch between 60 and 120 Hz. Charging is very fast with the stock charger: 25 Watts. Found out the 45W charger is no faster than 25. The ability to add an extra MicroSD card was very important for me. I installed a 512GB to hold all the video and pictures. Included headphones are nice, but there is no dedicated 1/8" jack. That's a minor complaint. The S20 Ultra does not have FM radio enabled like the old S10+, another minor complaint. Overall, I'm very pleased with the item.Less

review: If you are coming from anything before the s10 series battery life will be the number one plus. Focus issues that plagued the phone at initial release have been mostly solved and I haven't seen issues at all lately. Moment lenses are a great investment if you like taking pictures and don't have a DSLR camera on hand. I havent personally tried the 120hrz as I like the 3200x1440 setting.

review: Having owned the 1st gen SE for five years the battery was shot and I was contemplating replacing it for a while, but I'm glad I waited for the 3rd gen SE to come out - with the same A15 chip as the current flagship iPhone 13, and even the upcoming iPhone 14, it has performance to spare and is future proofed as far as any phone can be. Apps launch instantly, mobile 4g and 5g speeds match wifi performance (depending on the signal of course). I find battery life to be excellent - after a full day of use (for me that's at least 3 hours screen time using web, navigation, email, texting, photos/video, a few 10 min calls) I often still have 60% battery left the next morning. Whilst the LCD screen is small and unfashionable with its bezels, it is adequate for all my daily needs including email, etc. if you know you need a large screen for work or gaming, you're unlikely to be considering this phone anyway. For those who prefer a pocket sized phone, the screen is sharp and works well in all lighting conditions except direct bright sunlight where high contrast text is legible, but subtle tones and details in photos are hard to see (I've yet to see a screen that works well in such conditions). It also retains the home button and Touch ID which I appreciate and prefer to Face ID, especially when using banking apps and Apple Pay. The main camera is adequate for most situations and has Apple's latest image processing so the quality of photos and video is high. The front camera is of a lower resolution so selfies are not to the same standard. John Lewis sell at the same price as other retailers, but include a 2 year warranty which no one else does so represent excellent value for money.Less

review: See my YouTube review for the iPhone SE (2022) by typing: "iPhone SE 5G (2022) Starlight Review: Apple's Best Budget iPhone!" into the YouTube search. The Positives: ‚Ä¢ It has the A15 Bionic Chip. The most powerful smartphone chip in the world! ‚Ä¢ It takes great photos ‚Ä¢ It is 5G enabled ‚Ä¢ It has a longer battery life than the previous model ‚Ä¢ It will be supported with Apple iOS software updates for many years The Negatives: ‚Ä¢ It is an old design ‚Ä¢ It has a 7 megapixel camera on the front ‚Ä¢ There is no night mode ‚Ä¢ The phone is not as feature rich as the iPhone 13 models The Design The design of the SE is the same as the iPhone 8, a phone that was released almost 5 years ago. By today's standards this is old, but old doesn't necessarily mean bad as the SE is lightweight, comfortable to use and easy to carry on your person. The Camera The camera lenses/sensors are the same as the previous SE from 2020. There is a 12 megapixel lens on the back and a 7 megapixel lens on the front. However, although these are the same as the previous model the images this phone takes are fantastic, thanks (in part) to the SE's new image processing. For more information see my video review. The Performance! The new SE includes the latest A15 Bionic chip, the most powerful smartphone chip in the world. The Battery The battery should comfortably last over a day with medium use thanks to the larger battery and power efficiency of the A15 Bionic chip. 5G 5G is another big plus for this phone, but it's only useful if: a) You are in a 5G enabled area b) Have a good data (SIM) plan For the price the iPhone SE (2022) this is the most powerful phone you can get, a phone which will last many years to come.Less
